title: Geospatial mapping and science specialist (degree)
overviewOfRole: Analysing geographic data for things like maps, satellite navigation systems (satnav) and global positioning systems (GPS).
ssa1: 5 Construction, Planning and the Built Environment

knowledges.detail: Principles of safety: Health and safety standards, hazard identification, risk assessment, management and risk mitigation for self and others.
Mathematical principles and language: Differentiation and integration, algebra, functions and graphs, trigonometry, geometry, matrix algebra, least squares, and statistics.
Propose and use of surveying instruments, including traditional surveying instruments, automatic levels, total stations, scanners, cameras and Global Satellite Navigation Systems (GNSS).
Calculation methods to minimise error propagation when using surveying equipment, using and interpret determined error quantities.
Principles of geographical information science and the use of geographical information systems.
Built environment industry: Nature, extent, and context; organisations and personnel involved in planning, design, and development.
Design and construction process requirements: Social, environmental, legal, and economic performance.
Construction forms and components for the external and internal fabric of building projects.
Construction forms and components for civil engineering projects such as roads, rail and airports.
Functional and performance requirements of construction elements.

Data capture, registration and processing using Computer Aided Design (CAD) systems, Geographical Information Systems (GIS), Building Information Modelling (BIM), Digital Terrain Model (DTMs) and other specialist software to handle large datasets and produce accurate models.
Mapping products creation: Processes for 2D and 3D large-scale mapping from field survey data at various scales.
Critical thinking and problem-solving techniques.
Survey measurement systems: Characteristics of errors and uncertainty.
Monitoring and setting out: Procedures and problems.
Geotechnical concepts and principles.
Digital tools: Preparing desk studies and reports for construction projects.
Data acquisition technologies and techniques for capturing 3D datasets.
Quotation Preparation: Equipment costs, staff rates, and a project timeline, ensuring alignment with the company’s pricing structure and policies.
Calculating earthwork volumes and setting out data on construction sites.

Project management & reporting principles: From ‘cradle-to-grave including client’s design brief, planning and managing projects to adhere to the quoted specifications and timeline; documentation and reporting completion status, addressing any unforeseen issues, and identifying lessons learned.
Project Execution: Manage the project to adhere to the quoted specifications, standards, regulations and timelines.
Interpretation and understanding of maps, drawings, plans and 3D models in both digital and non-digital formats.
Social, commercial and ethical context when carrying out research in a specialist field.
Geospatial research methodologies: Qualitative and quantitative research, including laboratory testing, design, and case studies.
Principles of land registration and management systems and the relationship between them.
Professional surveyor: Role and requirements.
Inshore hydrographic survey for rivers, lakes and harbours to the appropriate datum, the health and safety requirements of these and using appropriate survey equipment and processing techniques.
Surveying at sea: Role in maritime safety and offshore industries and understanding the Instrumentation and processing techniques.
Boundary and cadastral surveys: Field and office procedures.
Legal and physical land boundaries: Definition and legal title.

Primary data capture techniques: The importance of accuracy, precision and modes of use including Global Satellite Navigation Systems (GNSS), automatic levels, total stations, laser scanning, photography and electronic sensing equipment.
Geospatial data analysis and management.
Plan and map data interpretation including legal documents.
Data security: Holding, retrieving and securing data, General Data Protection regulation (GDPR).
Geodesy principles: Coordinate systems, transformations, projections, datums, and their importance.
Land and sea law and regulations: Role of legal advisers.

Hydrographic: Principles and limitations of hydrographic survey: Assessment of survey requirements, equipment specifications and suitability, methods of collection, analysis, quality control and processing and presentation of hydrographic data.
Geospatial Engineering: Setting out and preparation techniques of data for 3-dimensional machine control, deformation monitoring and analysis of construction drawings and plans.

Sustainability in work and best practices including ‘One Planet Living’, balancing economic, environmental, and social objectives, minimising energy use, and using sustainable consumables in line with the UN sustainable development goals.
Client requirements and supervision: Understanding client needs, supervising tasks and others, and ensuring health, safety and environmental standards.
Principles of equity, diversity and inclusion.
Planned and unplanned CPD and recording methods.
Communication techniques: verbal and written.
Geospatial Engineering: Principles and limitations of geospatial engineering surveying.
Geospatial Engineering: Three-dimensional information preparation for input into machine control systems.
Geospatial Engineering: Techniques to create a survey control network and set out works based on design specifications.
Geospatial Engineering: Methods to set up monitoring survey control network and monitor structural deformation.

Hydrographic: Surveying techniques of still water (including lakes, ponds and reservoirs); and flowing water (including rivers, streams and tidal water) and the associated shoreline or underwater features.
Utilities surveying: Principles and limitations of utilities surveying.

Hydrographic: Tools for conducting hydrographic surveys such as traditional surveying instruments, automatic levels, total stations, laser scanning, photography, and Global Satellite Navigation Systems (GNSS).
Hydrographic: Methods for analysing hydrographic survey data, quality control and presenting findings.
Utilities: Laws and regulations relevant to utilities surveying.
Utilities: Methods for analysing utilities survey data, quality control and presenting findings.

Utilities: Surveying techniques for tracing, identifying and mapping underground utilities and service routes such as telecommunications, electricity distribution, natural gas, storm drains, foul drains, and water mains.
Utilities: Use of various tools to conduct utilities surveys such as radio frequency locators and ground penetrating radar.
Geospatial: Principles and limitations of geospatial surveying.
Geospatial: Impact of survey results on construction plans.
Geospatial: Geospatial surveying techniques such as 3D modelling and visualisation and boundary concerns.
Geospatial: Methods for analysing geospatial survey data, quality control and presenting findings.
Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Principles and limitations of Geographic Information Systems (GIS).
Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Compiling datasets from other sources including different data models, data formats, scales, projections and metadata standards and primary data collection.
Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) software for spatial analysis, data visualisation, map compilation and reporting.

Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Spatial analysis techniques to interpret geospatial data, enabling identification of patterns, relationships, and trends that inform decision-making in applications in urban planning, environmental management, and infrastructure development. data formats, metadata standards.

behaviours.detail: Act as a role model and advocate for health and safety across the team.
Act in a professional and ethical manner.
Collaborate and promote teamwork across disciplines.
Commit to their own and support others’ professional development.
Lead by example to promote accessibility, equality, diversity and inclusion.
Adapt and show resilience to challenging or changing situations.
Act as a role model and advocate environmental and sustainable practices.

skills.detail: Apply mathematics including basic operations, geometry, trigonometry & statistics to solve engineering, surveying and construction problems and present data graphically, differentiation and integration in tables and using appropriate software.
Undertake construction site visits and report on observed processes and management challenges.
Communicate with colleagues, clients and other stakeholders.
Interpret graphical information and written specifications related to building and civil engineering forms and components.
Produce simplified sketches to convey building details and information.
Evaluate suitability and limitations of mapping at different scales for particular purposes, taking into account the effect of projections.
Use of surveying equipment and processing software to produce maps and charts at appropriate various scales.
Plan and carry out mapping surveys involving control, detail survey, and graphical data presentation.
Use GIS software to perform exploratory analysis on geographical data, spatial and non-spatial.
Analyse the precision of measurements and resulting values in undertaking geospatial surveys.

Set up, verify, and operate various surveying instruments to minimise the effect of errors, for example, traditional surveying instruments, automatic levels, total stations, automated laser scanners, cameras and Global Satellite Navigation Systems (GNSS) to fix the level and position of points while minimising errors.
Plan projects ensuring they are managed based on available resources such as financial, material, staff and equipment.
Assess the profitability and commercial potential of ideas taking ethical, health, safety and environmental considerations into account.
Prepare quotes: ensuring they align with the company’s pricing structure and policies.

Manage projects to adhere to the quoted specifications, standards, regulations and timelines, identifying, managing and monitoring risks; reporting any unforeseen issues that arise, completions status, deviations from plan and lessons learned.
Plan, organise, and carry out engineering survey tasks according to client specifications.
Use digital data collection and survey processing software in survey applications.
Undertake coordinate transformations.
Assess survey control network designs with the integration of measurement techniques for geospatial surveying.
Solve and analyse least-squares estimation problems, including determination of the precision of unknown parameters.
Generate 3D models for Digital Terrain Model (DTMs), Digital Surface Model (DSMs), surface analysis, CAD, and BIM usage.
Carry out surveys using laser scanning and process point cloud datasets.
Use photogrammetry to create models and collect data.
Apply environmental and planning legislation to construction and surveying.
Research and identify design constraints, including environmental sustainability and risk assessment limitations, to develop solutions.
Interpret the requirements of land tenure and land registration systems.
Undertake and manage boundary and/or cadastral surveys, adopting appropriate scales and selecting supporting documentation.
Use and interpret photogrammetric digital imagery.
Identify and source datasets from various technologies (including laser scanning, remote sensing, and GIS) assessing quality and fitness for purpose to meet client requirements.
Use primary data capture techniques ensuring accuracy and precision and selecting the most suitable, coordinate systems, datums, transformations, and projections to meet project requirements.
Analyse and manage geospatial data, including plan and map data.
Evaluate complex information and survey issues and explain to clients.
Analyse data, present the survey results, and provide guidance to clients.
Apply and promote policies and practices to support equity, diversity, and inclusion.
Develop and extend professional knowledge.
Geospatial Engineering: Carry out site setting out from drawings, plans and design specification.
Geospatial Engineering: Gather and prepare data for 3D machine control, monitor deformation, and conduct as-built surveys.
Geospatial Engineering: Analyse and present findings of a geospatial engineering survey in line with design information and specification
Hydrographic: Plan hydrographic surveys, evaluating survey needs, equipment specifications, and their suitability in line with client requirements and approved specifications.
Hydrographic: Conduct hydrographic survey of a body of still or flowing water, including associated shoreline or underwater features, in line with client requirements and approved specifications.
Hydrographic: Analyse and present findings of a hydrographic survey in line with client needs and specifications.
Utilities: Plan utilities surveys, evaluating survey needs, equipment, specifications, and their suitability in line with client requirements and approved specifications.
Utilities: Conduct utilities surveys using technologies such as radio frequency locators and ground-penetrating radar.
Utilities: Analyse, quality control and present findings of a utilities survey in line with client needs and specifications.

Geospatial: Plan geospatial surveys evaluating the purpose of the survey, client's requirements, necessary equipment, survey area, level of detail, precision and accuracy needed, grid and datum to be used, and the format for presenting the data.
Geospatial: Conduct surveys using suitable equipment, for example laser scanners, total station, levels, drones.
Geospatial: Analyse and present findings of a geospatial survey in line with client needs and specifications.
Geospatial: Clarify complex survey topics, such as 3D modelling and visualisation, boundary concerns, and how survey results affect construction plans for clients.

Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Plan Geographic Information Systems (GIS) surveying, evaluating survey needs, equipment specifications, and their suitability in line with client requirements and approved specifications.
Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Conduct Geographic Information Systems (GIS) survey in line with client requirements and approved specifications.
Geographic Information Systems (GIS): Analyse and present findings of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) survey in line with client needs and specifications.

Ofqual
Earlsdon Park, 53-55 Butts Road, Coventry, CV1 3BH

involvedEmployers: Skanska (Lead Employer), Aecom, Balfour Beatty, Severn Partnership Ltd, Maltby Land Surveys Limited, Sir Robert McAlpine, Jacobs UK Limited, Ordnance Survey, Murphy Surveys, Subscan Technology Limited, Sitechnics Limited (trading name Technics Group), Topcon (Great Britain) Limited, Korec Group, Trimble, Malcolm Hughes Land Surveyors Limited, Leica Geosystems Limited, Cat Surveys Group Limited, Morgan Sindall Group, Historic England
englishAndMathsQualifications: <p>English and maths qualifications must be completed in line with the <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.gov.uk/guidance/apprenticeship-funding-rules" target="_blank">apprenticeship funding rules</a>.</p>
reviewDetails: this apprenticeship will be reviewed in accordance with our change request policy.
clusterDescription: Building/structure design, research, commercial cost management, contracts management with a wide range of knowledge of current technology developments and options, contracts, procurement and tracking. Consults with clients to determine functional and spatial requirements of new or renovated structures

qualifications.title: BSc/BSc(Hons) in a geospatial science subject that is accredited by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors or the Chartered Institution of Civil Engineering Surveyors.

professionalRecognition.bodyName: Chartered Institution of Civil Engineering Surveyors

duties.dutyDetail: Plan all geospatial activities in compliance with health, safety, and environmental regulations to ensure the health, safety and wellbeing of self and others at all times. and ensure compliance with environment and sustainability regulations. Report any non-compliance
Plan, organise, and manage geospatial projects, including determining coordinate reference systems, transformations, data collection methods, and quality control and assurance processes.

Collect and analyse geospatial data using various tools and techniques such as traditional surveying instruments, automatic levels, total stations, laser scanning, photogrammetry, and Global Satellite Navigation Systems (GNSS).

Process collected data using Computer Aided Design (CAD) systems, Geographical Information Systems (GIS), Building Information Modelling (BIM) analysis software and other specialist software to handle large datasets and produce accurate and precise models.
Ensure the precision and quality of geospatial data. Write technical reports and documentation.
Create visual representations of geospatial data such as 2D drawings, plans, charts and maps, 3D models and visualisations for various applications to include third party hosting platforms.
Collaborate with other professionals to understand their requirements and integrate geospatial data into broader project goals.
Promote sustainability in the built environment and address barriers in achieving sustainable goals, exploring technologies for achieving energy efficiency and lowering carbon footprint.
Apply geospatial expertise in various sectors such as land, air, offshore, civil engineering, construction, transportation, renewable energy, and entertainment.
Engage in both international and local projects, contributing to improvements in renewable energy, transport, residential developments, and more.
Actively communicate effectively with clients to understand their needs and deliver geospatial solutions that meet project specifications.
Integrate and manage geospatial data from various sources, ensuring appropriate precision, accuracy, interoperability and relevance for decision-making.
Contribute to the ongoing development of the geospatial profession by embracing new technologies and methodologies.
Adhere to ethical standards, regulations, legislation and sustainability practices within the geospatial profession and broader construction industry.
Advise management on subordinate staff and assist with training of juniors. Work with other team members to ensure effective co-ordination of survey projects.

Analyse construction drawings and models, set up survey control networks, set out the works using technologies, including GNSS, Total stations, and Levels, input into machine control software, check progress based on design specification, carry out any monitoring and as-built surveys.
Plan and conduct hydrographic surveys to measure water depth and identify underwater features and prepare all necessary plans and charts for a variety of uses

Conduct surveys to locate and map above and below ground utility networks, such as pipes, cables, telecommunications, electricity distribution, natural gas, storm drains, foul drains, and water mains before construction projects begin.
Collect geospatial data using various techniques, such as GNSS, remote sensing, laser scanners, total station, levels, UAV’s and electronic detection equipment and prepare plans and 3D models.

Capture and analyse spatial data to create detailed maps and models using GIS software, enabling the identification of patterns and trends that inform decision-making in various professional contexts.
